Goals

  • Sacrifice a little RAM for O(1) operations.
  • Sacrifice a little CPU for less memory churn.
  • Aggressively remove API that proves useless or confusing.
  • Aggressively abstract and hide complexity from the user.
  • Perfect is the enemy of Good.

Types

GraphFlag {...}{.size: 8.} = enum
  QueryResult = "the graph only makes sense in relation to another graph",
  UniqueNodes = "the nodes in the graph all have unique values",
  UniqueEdges = "the edges in the graph all have unique values",
  Directed = "edges have different semantics for source and target",
  Undirected = "edges have identical semantics for source and target",
  SelfLoops = "nodes may have edges that target themselves",
  Ultralight = "the graph is even lighter"
Graph[N; E; F] = ref GraphObj[N, E, F]

A collection of nodes and edges.

Nodes have a user-supplied .value of type N. Edges have a user-supplied .value of type E.

Node[N; E] = ref NodeObj[N, E]

A node in the graph.

Nodes have a user-supplied .value of type N. Edges have a user-supplied .value of type E.

Edge[N; E] = ref EdgeObj[N, E]

An edge connects two nodes.

Nodes have a user-supplied .value of type N. Edges have a user-supplied .value of type E.

GraphFlags = int
EdgeResult[N; E] = tuple[source: Node[N, E], edge: Edge[N, E], target: Node[N, E]]

Consts

defaultGraphFlags = {Directed, SelfLoops}

Procs

proc len[N, E; F: static[GraphFlags]](graph: Graph[N, E, F]): int
Return the number of nodes in a graph. O(1).

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
assert len(g) == 0
proc incl[N, E; F: static[GraphFlags]](graph: var Graph[N, E, F]; node: Node[N, E])
Includes a node in the graph. Has no effect if the node is already in the graph. O(1).

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
let n = g.add 3
var q = newGraph[int, string]()
q.incl n
q.incl n
assert len(q) == 1
proc add[N, E; F: static[GraphFlags]](graph: var Graph[N, E, F]; value: N): Node[N, E]
Creates a new node of value and adds it to the graph. Returns the new node. O(1).

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
discard g.add 3
assert len(g) == 1
discard g.add 9
assert len(g) == 2
proc contains[N, E; F: static[GraphFlags]](graph: Graph[N, E, F]; value: N): bool
Returns true if graph contains a node with the given value. Not yet O(1).

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
discard g.add 3
assert 3 in g
proc `[]`[N, E; F: static[GraphFlags]](graph: var Graph[N, E, F]; key: N): var Node[N, E]
Index a mutable graph to retrieve a mutable node of value key.

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
discard g.add 3
assert g[3].value == 3
proc clear[N, E; F: static[GraphFlags]](graph: var Graph[N, E, F])
Empty a graph of all nodes and edges.

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
discard g.add 3
clear(g)
assert len(g) == 0
proc del[N, E; F: static[GraphFlags]](graph: var Graph[N, E, F]; node: Node[N, E])
Remove a node from the graph; O(n). Has no effect if the node is not in the graph. Not O(1) yet.

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
let n = g.add 3
g.del n
assert len(g) == 0
proc edge[N, E; F: static[GraphFlags]](graph: var Graph[N, E, F]; node: var Node[N, E];
                                   value: E; target: var Node[N, E]): Edge[N, E]
Link node to target via a new edge of value; O(1).

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
discard g.add 3
discard g.add 27
let e = g.edge(g[3], "cubed", g[27])
assert e.value == "cubed"
assert g[3] in e
assert g[27] in e
proc `[]`[N, E](node: var Node[N, E]; key: E): var Node[N, E]
Index a node by edge key, returning the opposite (mutable) node.

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
discard g.add 3
discard g.add 9
let squared = g.edge(g[3], "squared", g[9])
let n9 = g[3]["squared"]
assert n9.value == 9
proc peers[N, E](node: Node[N, E]; target: Node[N, E]): bool
Returns true if node shares an edge with target.

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
var
  g3 = g.add 3
  g9 = g.add 9
assert not peers(g9, g3)
discard g.edge(g3, "squared", g9)
assert peers(g3, g9)
proc contains[N, E](edge: Edge[N, E]; value: N): bool
Returns true if edge links to a node with the given value; else false.

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
discard g.add 3
discard g.add 9
discard g.edge(g[3], "squared", g[9])
let n = g[9]
for source, edge, target in g.edges:
  assert 9 in edge
  assert 3 in edge
proc contains[N, E](edge: Edge[N, E]; node: Node[N, E]): bool
Returns true if the edge links to node; else false.

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
discard g.add 3
discard g.add 9
discard g.edge(g[3], "squared", g[9])
for source, edge, target in g.edges:
  assert source in edge
  assert target in edge
proc del[N, E](node: var Node[N, E]; edge: Edge[N, E])
Remove edge from node. Of course, this also removes edge from the target node on the opposite side. Not O(1) yet; indeed, it is relatively slow! 
proc del[N, E](node: var Node[N, E]; value: E)
Remove edge with value value from node. Of course, this also removes the edge from the target node on the opposite side. Not O(1) yet; indeed, it is relatively slow!

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
discard g.add 3
discard g.add 9
discard g.edge(g[3], "squared", g[9])
var n9 = g[3]["squared"]
n9.del "squared"
assert not peers(g[3], n9)
proc len[N, E](nodes: Nodes[N, E] | Edges[N, E]): int {...}{.
    deprecated: "count() conveys the O(N) cost".}
Deprecated: count() conveys the O(N) cost
Use count() instead; it expresses the O more clearly. 
proc contains[N, E](node: Node[N, E]; key: E): bool
Returns true if an edge with value key links node. Not yet O(1).

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
discard g.add 3
discard g.add 9
discard g.edge(g[3], "squared", g[9])
assert "squared" in g[3]
proc `$`[N, E](thing: Node[N, E] | Edge[N, E]): string
A best-effort convenience. 
proc `[]`[N, E](node: Node[N, E]; key: E): Node[N, E]
Index a node by edge key, returning the opposite node.

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
discard g.add 3
discard g.add 9
discard g.edge(g[3], "squared", g[9])
let
  l3 = g[3]
  l9 = g[3]["squared"]
assert l9.value == 9

Iterators

iterator outgoing[N, E](node: var Node[N, E]): tuple[edge: var Edge[N, E],
    target: var Node[N, E]]
Yield mutable outgoing edge and target target from a mutable node. 
iterator outgoing[N, E](node: Node[N, E]): tuple[edge: Edge[N, E], target: Node[N, E]]
Yield outgoing edge and target target from a node. 
iterator incoming[N, E](node: var Node[N, E]): tuple[edge: var Edge[N, E],
    source: var Node[N, E]]
Yield mutable incoming edge and source source from a mutable node. 
iterator incoming[N, E](node: Node[N, E]): tuple[edge: Edge[N, E], source: Node[N, E]]
Yield incoming edge and source source from a node. 
iterator neighbors[N, E](node: Node[N, E]): tuple[edge: Edge[N, E], node: Node[N, E]]
Yield edge and target node from a node. 
iterator items[N, E; F: static[GraphFlags]](graph: Graph[N, E, F]): Node[N, E]
Yield each node in the graph.

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
discard g.add 3
for node in items(g):
  assert node.value == 3
iterator edges[N, E; F: static[GraphFlags]](graph: Graph[N, E, F]): EdgeResult[N, E]
Yield source node, edge, and target node from a graph.

Example:

var g = newGraph[int, string]()
discard g.add 3
discard g.add 9
discard g.edge(g[3], "squared", g[9])
for source, edge, target in edges(g):
  assert edge.value == "squared"
  assert source.value == 3
  assert target.value == 9

Templates

template newGraph[N; E](flags: typed): auto
Create a new graph; nodes will hold N while edges will hold E. 
template newGraph[N; E](): auto
